original_text: Isogeometric analysis. The central idea of isogeometric analysis is to use the same ansatz functions for the discretization of the partial differential equation at hand, as are used for the representation of the problem geometry. Usually, the problem geometry Ω is represented in computer aided design (CAD) by means of NURBS or T-splines. This concept, originally invented in  [1] for finite element methods (IGAFEM) has proved very fruitful in applications  [1,2]; see also the monograph  [3]. Since CAD directly provides a parametrization of the boundary ∂Ω, this makes the boundary element method (BEM) the most attractive numerical scheme, if applicable (i.e., provided that the fundamental solution of the differential operator is explicitly known). Isogeometric BEM (IGABEM) has first been considered for 2D BEM in  [4] and for 3D BEM in  [5]. Unlike standard BEM with piecewise polynomials which is well-studied in the literature, cf. the monographs  [6,7] and the references therein, the numerical analysis of IGABEM is essentially open. We only refer to  [2,8–10] for numerical experiments and to  [11] for some quadrature analysis. In particular, a posteriori error estimation has been well-studied for standard BEM, e.g.,  [12–18] as well as the recent overview article  [19], but has not been treated for IGABEM so far. The purpose of the present work is to shed some first light on a posteriori error analysis for IGABEM which provides some mathematical foundation of a corresponding adaptive algorithm.
original_translation: Análisis isogeométrico. La idea central del análisis isogeométrico es utilizar las mismas funciones de ansatz para la discretización de la ecuación diferencial parcial en cuestión, que se utilizan para la representación de la geometría del problema. Por lo general, la geometría del problema Ω se representa en diseño asistido por computadora (CAD) mediante NURBS o T-splines. Este concepto, originalmente inventado en [1] para los métodos de elementos finitos (IGAFEM), ha demostrado ser muy fructífero en aplicaciones [1,2]; ver también la monografía [3]. Dado que el CAD proporciona directamente una parametrización del contorno ∂Ω, esto convierte al método de los elementos de contorno (BEM) en el esquema numérico más atractivo, si es aplicable (es decir, siempre que se conozca explícitamente la solución fundamental del operador diferencial). El método de los elementos isogeométricos con el método de los elementos de contorno (IGABEM) se consideró por primera vez para el método de los elementos de contorno en 2D en [4] y en 3D en [5]. A diferencia del BEM estándar con polinomios a trozos, que está bien estudiado en la literatura, cf. los monográficos [6,7] y las referencias incluidas, el análisis numérico de IGABEM es esencialmente abierto. Solo nos referimos a [2,8-10] para experimentos numéricos y a [11] para algunos análisis de cuadratura. En particular, la estimación de errores a posteriori ha sido ampliamente estudiada para el método de elementos de contorno estándar, por ejemplo, [12–18], así como en el reciente artículo de revisión [19], pero aún no ha sido abordada para el método de elementos de contorno isogeométricos. El propósito del presente trabajo es arrojar algo de luz inicial sobre un análisis de error a posteriori para IGABEM que proporciona una base matemática de un algoritmo adaptativo correspondiente.

original_annotated_sentences: Isogeometric analysis.

The central idea of isogeometric analysis is to use the same ansatz functions for the discretization of the partial differential equation at hand, as are used for the representation of the problem geometry.
Usually, the problem geometry Ω is represented in computer aided design (CAD) by means of NURBS or T-splines.
This concept, originally invented in  [1] for finite element methods (IGAFEM) has proved very fruitful in applications  [1,2]; see also the monograph  [3].

Since CAD directly provides a parametrization of the boundary ∂Ω, this makes the
boundary element method
(BEM) the most attractive numerical scheme, if applicable (i.e., provided that the fundamental solution of the differential operator is explicitly known).
Isogeometric BEM (IGABEM) has first been considered for 2D BEM in  [4] and for 3D BEM in  [5].
Unlike standard BEM with piecewise polynomials which is well-studied in the literature, cf. the monographs  [6,7] and the references therein, the numerical analysis of IGABEM is essentially open.
We only refer to  [2,8–10] for numerical experiments and to  [11] for some quadrature analysis.
In particular, a posteriori error estimation has been well-studied for standard BEM, e.g.,  [12–18] as well as the recent overview article  [19], but has not been treated for IGABEM so far.
The purpose of the present work is to shed some first light on a posteriori error analysis for IGABEM which provides some mathematical foundation of a corresponding adaptive algorithm.

Análisis isogeométrico. La idea central del análisis isogeométrico es utilizar las mismas funciones de ansatz para la discretización de la ecuación diferencial parcial en cuestión, que se utilizan para la representación de la geometría del problema. Por lo general, la geometría del problema Ω se representa en diseño asistido por computadora (CAD) mediante NURBS o T-splines. Este concepto, originalmente inventado en [1] para los métodos de elementos finitos (IGAFEM), ha demostrado ser muy fructífero en aplicaciones [1,2]; ver también la monografía [3]. Output: Dado que CAD proporciona directamente una parametrización del límite ∂Ω, esto hace que el
método de elementos de contorno
(BEM) sea el esquema numérico más atractivo, si es aplicable (es decir, siempre que la solución fundamental del operador diferencial sea conocida explícitamente). El método de los elementos isogeométricos con el método de los elementos de contorno (IGABEM) se consideró por primera vez para el método de los elementos de contorno en 2D en [4] y en 3D en [5]. A diferencia del BEM estándar con polinomios a trozos, que está bien estudiado en la literatura, cf. los monográficos [6,7] y las referencias incluidas, el análisis numérico de IGABEM es esencialmente abierto. Solo nos referimos a [2,8-10] para experimentos numéricos y a [11] para algunos análisis de cuadratura. En particular, la estimación de errores a posteriori ha sido ampliamente estudiada para el método de elementos de contorno estándar, por ejemplo, [12–18], así como en el reciente artículo de revisión [19], pero aún no ha sido abordada para el método de elementos de contorno isogeométricos. El propósito del presente trabajo es arrojar algo de luz inicial sobre un análisis de error a posteriori para IGABEM que proporciona una base matemática de un algoritmo adaptativo correspondiente.

Solo nos referimos a [2,8-10] para experimentos numéricos y a [11] para algunos análisis de cuadratura. En particular, la estimación de errores a posteriori ha sido ampliamente estudiada para el método de elementos de contorno estándar, por ejemplo, [12–18], así como en el reciente artículo de revisión [19], pero aún no ha sido abordada para el método de elementos de contorno isogeométricos. El propósito del presente trabajo es arrojar algo de luz inicial sobre un análisis de error a posteriori para IGABEM que proporciona una base matemática de un algoritmo adaptativo correspondiente.

isogeometric analysis
.

The central idea of
isogeometric analysis
is to use the same ansatz functions for the discretization of the partial differential equation at hand, as are used for the representation of the problem geometry.
Usually, the problem geometry Ω is represented in computer aided design (CAD) by means of NURBS or T-splines.
This concept, originally invented in  [1] for finite element methods (IGAFEM) has proved very fruitful in applications  [1,2]; see also the monograph  [3].

Since CAD directly provides a parametrization of the boundary ∂Ω, this makes the boundary element method (BEM) the most attractive numerical scheme, if applicable (i.e., provided that the fundamental solution of the differential operator is explicitly known).
Isogeometric BEM (IGABEM) has first been considered for 2D BEM in  [4] and for 3D BEM in  [5].
Unlike standard BEM with piecewise polynomials which is well-studied in the literature, cf. the monographs  [6,7] and the references therein, the numerical analysis of IGABEM is essentially open.
We only refer to  [2,8–10] for numerical experiments and to  [11] for some quadrature analysis.
In particular, a posteriori error estimation has been well-studied for standard BEM, e.g.,  [12–18] as well as the recent overview article  [19], but has not been treated for IGABEM so far.
The purpose of the present work is to shed some first light on a posteriori error analysis for IGABEM which provides some mathematical foundation of a corresponding adaptive algorithm.

original_annotated_sentences: Isogeometric analysis.

The central idea of isogeometric analysis is to use the same ansatz functions for the discretization of the partial differential equation at hand, as are used for the representation of the
problem geometry
.

Usually, the
problem geometry
Ω is represented in computer aided design (CAD) by means of NURBS or T-splines.
This concept, originally invented in  [1] for finite element methods (IGAFEM) has proved very fruitful in applications  [1,2]; see also the monograph  [3].

Since CAD directly provides a parametrization of the boundary ∂Ω, this makes the boundary element method (BEM) the most attractive numerical scheme, if applicable (i.e., provided that the fundamental solution of the differential operator is explicitly known).
Isogeometric BEM (IGABEM) has first been considered for 2D BEM in  [4] and for 3D BEM in  [5].
Unlike standard BEM with piecewise polynomials which is well-studied in the literature, cf. the monographs  [6,7] and the references therein, the numerical analysis of IGABEM is essentially open.
We only refer to  [2,8–10] for numerical experiments and to  [11] for some quadrature analysis.
In particular, a posteriori error estimation has been well-studied for standard BEM, e.g.,  [12–18] as well as the recent overview article  [19], but has not been treated for IGABEM so far.
The purpose of the present work is to shed some first light on a posteriori error analysis for IGABEM which provides some mathematical foundation of a corresponding adaptive algorithm.
